Culinary Profile & Uses
1. Flavour and Form

‘Narrow-Leaf Nano’ offers the true tarragon signature: a sophisticated, sweet licorice-anise flavour with a distinct, pleasant peppery-astringent finish that lingers on the palate. Its leaves are long, narrow, glossy, and a vibrant dark green, growing on a compact, upright, and less woody plant than standard French tarragon.

2. The Soul of French Sophistication

This herb is a cornerstone of French gastronomy and must be used with a delicate hand to preserve its nuanced flavour.

  • Fines Herbes & Béarnaise: The essential, non-negotiable component of the fines herbes blend and the defining flavour in Béarnaise sauce, where its aniseed character complements the richness of egg yolk and butter.
  • Chicken & Seafood: A classic pairing with chicken (Poulet à l’Estragon), fish (especially salmon), and in creamy sauces for shellfish, where its sweetness enhances without overpowering.
  • Vinegars & Dressings: The premier herb for infusing white wine vinegar, creating a foundational ingredient for sophisticated vinaigrettes and marinades.
3. The Harvest and Yield

The plant is a sterile, clump-forming perennial that must be propagated from cuttings or divisions, which is how this cultivar is supplied as a pre-vegetated plug. Harvest by snipping the tips of the stems. It provides a modest but potent yield of 5–15g of precious leaves per week. Its flavour is so intense that a few leaves are all that’s needed.
